item.title: Diablo 4's Goblin Greedings Lets You Beat Up Goblins For More Loot
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's not an easy life for Sanctuary's citizens in Diablo 4, but players can make things a little brighter in the upcoming holiday event Goblin Greedings. Starting on December 18, players will be to put presents under their tree--so to speak--by clobbering creatures for loot and bringing a little hope back to Estuar.

To claim their prizes, players will have to face hordes of Treasure Goblins and earn their place on the March of the Goblins reputation board. There are multiple tiers to unlock, and players can claim their prizes between each one by visiting the Goblin Square in Kyovashad. Once players complete the final tier, they will be given a Resplendent Spark. That final tier is repeatable, and the quality of the loot dropped by enemies will increase with each tier. However, players will only have until January 6, 2026 to work their way through and claim as much treasure as they can.

Returning Grim Favors during Goblin Greedings will also give players an additional cache for Gift of the Tree. All they need to do to claim it is to select a cache, which will reveal the treasure they've been given by the Gift of the Tree.

Additionally, a handful of free holiday items will appear at the in-game store on specific dates:

  • December 18: Tackle of the First Snows (Mount Trophy)
  • December 19: Fallow-ward (Mount Trophy)
  • December 20: Crook of First Snow (Mount Armor)

As with the rest of treasures, those items will disappear after January 6.

Outside of the game, the prequel to next year's Lord of Hatred expansion, Diablo 4: The Lost Horadrim, is available for preorder now. Preordering the expansion itself grants players early access to Paladins, one of the latest classes added to the game. The expansion is also bringing back the fan-favorite villain, Lilith.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Get 25 PC Games For $64 With This New Fanatical Deal
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fanatical is closing 2025 out with a new build-your-own bundle deal, the Best of Platinum Collection. This deal offers a selection of various acclaimed PC games featured in the various Platinum Collection bundles throughout 2025, giving you a chance to pick up some excellent games for cheap. Like Fanatical's other build your own bundle promotions, you can pick as many games from the list as you'd like, and the more games you buy, the more you save. To start, you can pick up to four games for $3.33 each. At five or more games, you'll pay $3 per item. Grab 10 or more games, and you'll pay just $2.90 per game, and if you want the full 22-game bundle, it'll run you $63.78, a $547.75 value--not too shabby for literally thousands of hours of entertainment.

One of the items you can pick, the SteamWorld Classic Bundle, comes with four games: SteamWorld Dig, SteamWorld Dig 2, SteamWorld Heist, and SteamWorld Quest: Hand of Gilgamech. So, really, if you decide to add this to the Best of Platinum Collection, it could be a total of 25 games. The list of possible games also includes the strategy game SteamWorld Build as another pick, in case you want to load up on even more of the series.

With season 2 of the Fallout TV show looming, now's the perfect time to explore the open-world RPGs that inspired the show with Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition and Fallout New Vegas: Ultimate Edition. Both are available as part of the Best of Platinum Collection. These versions include the full base games plus every update, add-on, and DLC expansion. You can round out the selection with Fallout 76, which is an online multiplayer take on the series--though it still offers the same open-ended, first-person exploration and RPG gameplay as the other games. It also recently received a new Burning Springs DLC update that ties into the Amazon Prime Video streaming series.

For you horror fans, one of the biggest highlights of the Platinum Collection is the inclusion of Amnesia: The Bunker. The Amnesia games are some of the most tense, atmospheric, and terrifying survival horror games to be found in the genre, and getting it at this price is a steal.

Plenty of other games are available in Fanatical's Platinum Collection, including the narrative-driven RPG Disco Elysium: The Final Cut, the hidden FPS gem RoboCop: Rogue City, the Lego-themed puzzle game Lego Bricktales, and more. Check out the full list below.

Fanatical Best of Platinum Collection: Build Your Own Bundle (2025)

  • Amnesia: The Bunker
  • Botany Manor
  • Disco Elysium: The Final Cut
  • Doom (2016)
  • Dungeon Tycoon
  • Dysmantle
  • Edge of Sanity
  • Endless Alice
  • Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition
  • Fallout 76
  • Fallout New Vegas: Ultimate Edition
  • Gestalt: Steam & Cinder
  • The Isletide Hotel
  • LEGO Brick Tales
  • Mini Settlers
  • Neon Garten
  • The Pale Beyond
  • Paradise Killer
  • Reveil
  • RoboCop: Rogue City
  • SteamWorld Build
  • SteamWorld Classic Bundle

If none of these games are quite your bag or you're after something different, there are plenty of other bundle deals through Fanatical. Right in time for the Winter holidays, there's the Build Your Own Holiday Bundle that has a ton of fun indie titles to explore. There are 29 days to claim these games, and if you want the entire 18-game package, it'll run you just $8.49, a $291.75 value.

If you like the RNG aspect of games, Fanatical also has a handful of Mystery Bundles to choose from. There's the RPG Mystery Bundle, where you can get one mystery game key for just $1.49, two game keys for $2.79, or three game keys for $3.69. It's a gamble, but knowing Fanatical, these titles will be well worth these prices.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: Arc Raiders Groundbreaking Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Groundbreaking quest in Arc Raiders takes place on the perpetually busy and dangerous Blue Gate map, and it has multiple objectives that send you to its northern region. If you're looking to find the locked room at Pilgrim's Peak, or need to know where to find the building pictured on the whiteboard, we'll fill you in on how to complete this quest here.

You don't need to extract to complete Groundbreaking, but you'll receive the Blue Gate Communication Tower Key upon accepting this request, so you need to bring it into the raid with you. As such, you'll want to bring an augment with a safe pocket so that you don't accidentally lose this key during your journey to Pilgrim's Peak. If you do lose it, you'll have to wait to find another one (which is entirely random) or just hope you can catch the door open from someone else's key at some point.

When you're ready to complete the Groundbreaking quest, read on.

Enter the locked room at Pilgrim's Peak

The first step in Groundbreaking is to head to Pilgrim's Peak. This is the northernmost POI on the map and is commonly searched by other raiders for its high-tier loot. As such, approach this area with caution and be sure the Blue Gate Communication Tower Key is in your safe pocket.

When you arrive, head inside and find the locked door on the eastern side of the facility.

This door is easy to spot, though it's always possible someone else will have opened it when you arrive. If that's the case, save your key to use for a loot run later.

Head inside the room.

Search the room for any construction research

Inside the room, interact with the lone whiteboard on the right side to discover a picture of a building.

While you're here, it's not a bad idea to loot everything, as you may find some really great stuff in here. Keep an eye out for a weapon case that may even have a good gun you can equip to help you survive the rest of the raid.

When you're done, it's time to find the building pictured on the whiteboard.

Find the building pictured on the whiteboard

Next, you'll need to head southwest to the Abandoned Housing Project POI. Note that this is a common spawn point, so it's always possible you'll run into someone looting around here. Be careful.

Walk down to the building just below the words "Abandoned Housing Project" on your map to trigger the next objective: Take a photograph of the abandoned housing project.

Photograph the abandoned housing project

Approach any of the interactable spots around this unfinished building to take a photograph. This will complete the quest.

With the quest complete, you're now able to head back to Speranza using your preferred extraction point. Blue Gate is well-known for having extraction campers, so check any buildings or nooks and crannies around the extraction point before you start it, and keep your gun out just in case anyone pops up. You've got this, raider.

For more on Arc Raiders, check out our comprehensive guides hub.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Save Big On A 1,910-Piece Claw Machine Building Set That Actually Works
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Over the past five years, building-set manufacturer Pantasy has made a name for itself with impressive brick-built models. Pantasy's catalog includes officially licensed building sets based on Astro Boy, Garfield, The Little Prince, and Dragon Ball Z as well as a series of retro-inspired tech models. One of Pantasy's newest building sets might be its most ambitious: a working claw machine game. If that sounds cool to you, you have until 12 AM PT (December 17) to snag the 1,910-piece build for its lowest price yet. Normally $140 on Amazon and $150 on Pantasy's site, the Claw Machine is on sale for $99.

Amazon's limited-time deal drops the price to $109, but you can save an additional $10 by clicking the coupon box on the store page. After reading about this extremely cool building set, you can check out our roundup of the best Pantasy building deals at the bottom of this story, including an officially licensed iGame Gaming Desktop for $64 (was $70), Sherlock Holmes' 3,000-plus piece apartment for $99.19 (was $130), a Retro Gumball Machine for $59.49 (was $80), and the Retro Desktop Computer for $75 (was $90).

If you've only ever built Lego sets, it's worth noting Pantasy's bricks are fully compatible with Lego. This is common with non-Lego building sets, including Mega Bloks, Jazware's BLDR, and Brick Shop Hot Wheels cars.

Pantasy Claw Machine Building Set (1,910 Pieces)

$99 (was $140) | Limited-time deal

Pantasy has designed some really cool building sets, including officially licensed Astro Boy models, a replica gaming PC, a retro computer, a gumball machine, and many others. From an interactive perspective, though, the Claw Machine might be Pantasy's most ambitious product yet.

Recommended for builders ages 14 and up, the 1,910-piece Claw Machine is a complex build with a wide variety of piece types. It has five electronic modules powered by USB-C: the motor to make the claw respond to arcade stick movements, speakers to play music and sound effects, a control unit for the stick, an on/off switch, and LED lights that flash when playing.

The set also comes with eight brick-built prizes to place inside the gashapon capsules: clown hat, circus tent, crystal ball, train, cat, gift box, deck of cards, and jack-in-the-box.

The completed machine is 11.8 x 10.55 x 17.7 inches. The colorful circus theme looks great. Along with decorative shapes along the edges, the top of the machine has a circus sign flanked by a buildable clown display figure, a rabbit in a magician's black top hat, and balloons.

More Pantasy Building Set Deals at Amazon

Here's a list of the tech-focused Pantasy sets on sale right now, including the awesome Astro Boy robot figure. The 1,250-piece model shows the internal mechanical components on one side. With Christmas around the corner, Amazon has Pantasy's 1,056-piece Christmas Tree model that lights up for $54.49 (was $70).

  • Astro Boy Robot Figure (1,250 pieces) -- $69.29 ($90)
  • iGame Gaming PC (1,010 pieces) -- $64 ($70)
  • Retro Gumball Machine (892 pieces) -- $59.49 ($80)
  • Retro Jukebox (1,273 pieces) -- $69.29 ($90)
  • Retro Phonograph (646 pieces) -- $49.49 ($70)
  • Retro Computer + Keyboard/Mouse (1,800 pieces) -- $75 ($90)
  • Retro Computer + Keyboard/Mouse (1,634 pieces) -- $62 ($90)
  • Retro Phone (766 pieces) -- $49.79 ($60)
  • Retro Microscope (1,107 pieces) -- $59.49 ($70)
  • Steampunk Airship (1,949 pieces) -- $89.59 ($120)
  • Steampunk Submarine (2,552 pieces) -- $89.59 ($120)
  • Steampunk Windmill Workshop (2,450 pieces) -- $99.19 ($130)
  • Motorized Cuckoo Clock (2,163 pieces) -- $90 ($120)
  • Light-up Christmas Tree (1,056 pieces) -- $54.49 ($70)
  • Garfield Coffee Maker (301 pieces) -- $35
  • The Little Prince Hourglass (670 pieces) -- $39.49 ($70)
  • The Little Prince Starry Adventure (797 pieces) -- $42.49 ($50)
  • The Little Prince Suitcase Diorama (519 pieces) -- $31 ($40)
  • The Little Prince Dome Dioramas (~200 pieces) -- $18.74 ($30) each

Pantasy also makes highly detailed architecture sets, including a theater, a toy shop, a beer brewery, a pirate-themed pub, and even Sherlock Holmes' apartment. These models have modular designs with detailed interiors and often eclipse 3,000 pieces.

  • Sherlock Holmes: Baker Street 221B Apt (3,087 pieces) -- $99.19 ($130)
  • Big Ben Clock Tower (2,723 pieces) -- $75 ($100)
  • Blossom Cafe (2,826 pieces) -- $109 ($140)
  • Craft Brewery (3,266 pieces) -- $117.49 ($150)
  • Motorcycle Restaurant (2,944 pieces) -- $88.79 ($140)
  • The Opera Theater (3,518 pieces) -- $139.59 ($170)
  • The Pirates Pub (2,858 pieces) -- $98.79 ($140)
  • Toy Store (2,978 pieces) -- $109.19 ($140)
  • Western Mine (2,850 pieces) -- $109 ($140)
  • Winter Summit Ski Lodge (3,135 pieces) -- $120 ($150)

For more budget-friendly brick sets based on retro tech, check out these four combo packs made by JMBricklayer. For $25.49, you can build three small models: a desktop computer model, a boombox, and a knockoff Famicom.
